pullRequest.title: SB Track2 : Adding application Id to be set in UserAgent.
pullRequest.bodyText:
Provide support for adding application-id in user agent.
Note(9/3/2020):
We are going to wait for September release to complete and merge this PR after that .  Since we need to do similar change in EH for this feature.

commit.message: SB Track2 : Adding application Id to be set in UserAgent.

nodes.bodyText: Since Event Hubs depends on implementation classes in azure-core-amqp. This will break it. Have you checked to make sure it works there?

A static client logger should be used for a helper class that only has static methods.
Why do we need content type in client options? Do we have a usecase where customers would want to set this?
The return type should be ServiceBusAdministrationClientBuilder

commit.message: Fixing pom and some compile time errors

nodes.bodyText: Why can't it be null? It is by default null so it seems reasonable for a user to null it out if they don't want it set any longer?
This is not consistent with the behavior of Header itself, where the value gets appended to the header.
Don't talk about implementation details in API documentation.
I don't think we need to do this. We should deprecate the HttpLogOptions one, and have it take lower precedence to the clientOptions one (so we only use it when the clientOptions one is not set).
I think this can be improved, based on my other comment in this review.

nodes.bodyText: Have you reproduced this logic for application ID length, spaces, etc in the new location?

It's better to pass the whole ClientOptions here since we might need the headers and other options that will be added there. It's easier to plumb this in once and not keep adding new params to this constructor.
nit: move all constants to the top of the class.
I don't think we need any of these methods on the ClientOptions class. We should just have getter method for returning the header collection.
This line should be removed.
Why is this hardcoded to empty string?
Do you really need this suppression?

nodes.bodyText: If you name "validateApplicationId" parameter the same as the test method name, you don't need to specify it. The framework can infer what the arguments are. And you can use @methodSource
I told Hemant to save the EventHubs implementation one to another PR. I was trying to scope this PR. There is another open issue for Event Hubs.
This will throw NPE if logOptions is null.
What is using this logger? I see it is a newly added property but no new code uses it.
If value is null does this return name: or name:null?

Mind giving an example on how this class would be used? Is it expected to be passed during the construction of an SDK client or for each service call made?
Right now, UserAgentPolicy has an immutable User-Agent string, so it feels like this would be passed during client construction only?
I'm not fond of having this in our public API
This javadoc could be improved.

Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                 * Sets the provided headers.
          
          
            
                 * Sets the provided headers, overwriting all previously-set headers in the process.
You might want to consider making this lazily instantiated
Once the applicationId is set, this seems to prevent it ever being reset? If that is desirable (which I don't think it is), then it is not documented.
Please be sure to review all JavaDoc to ensure it is readable.

nodes.bodyText: Another JavaDoc to flesh out, especially before it gets replicated across all libraries.
Rather than return a new arraylist - just return an empty iterable, e.g. return Collections.emptyList();

I would be more direct:

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                 * @deprecated deprecated in favor of {@link ClientOptions#getApplicationId()}
          
          
            
                 * @deprecated Use {@link ClientOptions} to configured {@code applicationId}.

I think we should leave the second sentence out if we ever want to use this in different ways. It also doesn't add much explanation about the usage of this class.

Any reason to require the user to set the entire Iterable rather than offering a setHeaders(Header...), or setHeaders(Iterable<Header>), and addHeader(Header) operators? I feel this will lead to a lot of situations where the user will need to use Collections.singletonList().
Need to add a @throws Javadoc.
Why do we prevent null here when the getter will return an empty list on null?

Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                 * Sets the provided headers, overwriting all previously-set headers in the process. It will be applied on the
          
          
            
                 * Sets the headers, overwriting all previously set headers in the process. It will be applied on the
I think the second sentence should be made into another paragraph as it is details on how the values passed to the setter will be used.

Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
             * It represents a single header for a request being sent to Azure Service.
          
          
            
             * Represents a single header for a request.
          
      
    
    
  

Can drop the Azure bit as it isn't explicitly required for our SDKs to talk to Azure services.

nodes.bodyText: We should see if it is cheaper to store the values as a String[], List<String>, or String. Not required for this PR.
Can this be made final?
Yeah, this creates a new instance of ArrayList each time. Instead, using Collections.emptyList() will return a static singleton list instance.
It seems like the ctor does not check for null value but addValue does. We should either consistently do the null check.
This can throw NPE if the ctor set the value to null and then trying to concat to the null value.
I don't think this is necessary. If we find the app id in ClientOptions, there's no need to check HttpLogOptions at all. App id in ClientOptions will always have higher priority.
Typo on 'configured' here and elsewhere.

-     * @deprecated deprecated in favor of {@link ClientOptions#getApplicationId()}
+     * @deprecated Use {@link ClientOptions} to configured {@code applicationId}.

nodes.bodyText: There is no need for a new paragraph for the second sentence.

I'd really like another pass on this JavaDoc, because it is not as descriptive as it would ideally be. It doesn't explain what it means to set various options on the client (and why that is different from other builder parameters), it doesn't explain where users can use this API. It doesn't explain very clearly what a Header is, and how an http or other header might be created and passed in. It doesn't explain what exactly an application ID is and why it might be useful to set it.
In other words, put yourself in the seat of someone new to this API and be sure you're explaining to them everything they need to know. Same goes for the clientOptions API on builders, especially as the rest of the team will copy / paste that content.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,89 @@ +// Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved. +// Licensed under the MIT License. + +package com.azure.core.util; + +import com.azure.core.annotation.Fluent; +import com.azure.core.util.logging.ClientLogger; +import com.azure.core.http.policy.UserAgentPolicy; + +import java.util.Collections; + +/** + * This class represents various options to be set on the client. + *

+ * The {@link Header} could be set using {@link ClientOptions#setHeaders(Iterable) setHeaders}. The {@link Header} will + * be applied on the request being sent to Azure Service. + *

+ * The {@code applicationId} could be set using {@link ClientOptions#setApplicationId(String) setApplicationId} which + * is used for setting {@code applicationId} in the {@link UserAgentPolicy}. + */

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change /** * Sets the {@link ClientOptions} which enables various options to be set on the client. For example setting * {@code applicationId} using {@link ClientOptions#setApplicationId(String)} to configure {@link UserAgentPolicy} * for telemetry/monitoring purpose. *

* More About Azure Core: Telemetry policy * * @param clientOptions to be set on the client. * * @return The updated {@link ServiceBusClientBuilder} object. * @see ClientOptions */ /** * Sets the {@link ClientOptions} to be sent from the client built from this builder, enabling customization of * certain properties, as well as support the addition of custom header information. Refer to the * {@link ClientOptions} documentation for more information. * * @param clientOptions to be set on the client. * @return The updated {@link ServiceBusClientBuilder} object. */
